note_text:
Bronchoscopic Lung Volume Reduction Note
Procedure: Zephyr endobronchial valve placement in right upper lobe
Patient: Maria Lopez, 64-year-old female with severe heterogeneous emphysema and hyperinflation.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.5 ETT; volume control ventilation.
Target lobe selection: Right upper lobe based on CT fissure analysis, perfusion scan, and quantitative CT. Chartis catheter evaluation demonstrated absence of collateral ventilation in RUL.
Intervention: Four Zephyr valves placed to occlude RUL segments (RB1, RB2, RB3, RB4+5 combined). Complete occlusion confirmed bronchoscopically.
Complications: Small right pneumothorax on immediate postprocedure CXR requiring 14 Fr pigtail chest tube.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit for monitoring with chest tube to water seal.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction for severe RUL-predominant emphysema
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Severe heterogeneous emphysema with RUL predominance; intact fissures on CT
registry_entry.prior_therapy: Maximal inhaler therapy and pulmonary rehab
registry_entry.blvr_cv_assessment_method: CT fissure analysis, perfusion scanning, Chartis
registry_entry.pleural_procedure_type: Chest tube placement for BLVR pneumothorax
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: None during bronchoscopy; postprocedure pneumothorax treated with chest tube
registry_entry.pneumothorax_intervention: 14 Fr pigtail chest tube to water seal
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Severe emphysema treated with BLVR to RUL; postprocedure pneumothorax
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR until pneumothorax resolved; outpatient follow-up with PFTs at 4–6 weeks

coding_review.rvu_data_source: ip_coding_billing.v2_7 (numeric 2025 facility RVUs and payments should be populated downstream from this source).
coding_review.rationale: Documentation shows emphysema patient underwent Zephyr bronchial valve placement in the right upper lobe with Chartis assessment and four valves placed, supporting 31647 for BLVR, and a separate ultrasound-guided pigtail chest tube was placed and left in place for postprocedure pneumothorax, supporting additional code 32557.

note_text:
Bronchoscopic Lung Volume Reduction Note
Procedure: Attempted Zephyr valve placement in left upper lobe aborted due to collateral ventilation
Patient: Steven Brooks, 70-year-old male with severe emphysema.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.0 ETT.
Summary:
- Target lobe: Left upper lobe based on CT heterogeneity and fissure completeness.
- Chartis assessment revealed persistent airflow consistent with significant collateral ventilation; BLVR not performed.
- No valves deployed. Airways irrigated and inspected.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Extubated in procedure room and discharged home after observation.

note_text:
Whole Lung Lavage Procedure Note
Procedure: Right whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
Patient: Jason Phillips, 39-year-old male with autoimmune PAP, status post left lung lavage 3 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 39 Fr left-sided double-lumen tube, single-lung ventilation of left lung.
Lavage details: Right lung lavaged with warmed saline aliquots of 800–1000 mL. Total instilled volume 32 L; total effluent 27 L of progressively clearing milky fluid.
Complications: Brief episode of hypotension treated with vasopressor bolus; oxygenation adequate throughout.
Disposition: Remained intubated postprocedure and transferred to ICU on mechanical ventilation.

note_text:
Whole Lung Lavage Note (Abbreviated)
Procedure: Partial left lung lavage for PAP
Patient: Lauren Young, 46-year-old female with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and poor cardiopulmonary reserve.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with right-sided DLT. Plans for staged smaller-volume lavages.
Course: Left lung lavaged with 10 L of warm saline in 500–800 mL aliquots. Procedure terminated early due to rising airway pressures and modest hypoxia; total return 8.4 L.
Complications: Hypoxemia to 82%, responsive to recruitment and switch to two-lung ventilation.
Disposition: Extubated in OR to high-flow nasal cannula and admitted to ICU.

note_text:
Foreign Body Bronchoscopy Note
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with removal of chicken bone from left lower lobe bronchus
Patient: Michael James, 45-year-old male with acute onset cough after eating chicken wings, CT showing airway foreign body.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with rigid adult bronchoscope and jet ventilation.
Findings: Sharp bone fragment lodged in superior segment bronchus of LLL with surrounding granulation tissue.
Intervention: Bone removed piecemeal using rigid forceps and basket; granulation cauterized with APC. Airways suctioned clear.
Complications: Brief desaturation to 86%, resolved with bag ventilation.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and observed for 4 hours on the ward.

note_text:
Pediatric Bronchoscopy Note
Procedure: Rigid bronchoscopy with removal of pen cap from right mainstem bronchus
Patient: Ava Thompson, 6-year-old female who aspirated pen cap while playing at school.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with pediatric rigid bronchoscope.
Findings: Hollow plastic pen cap lodged in proximal right mainstem causing near-complete obstruction of RUL and RML.
Intervention: Foreign body grasped and removed intact with optical forceps. Airways suctioned and inspected to subsegmental level.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Extubated in OR and observed in pediatric recovery; discharged home later that day.

note_text:
Bronchial Thermoplasty Procedure Note
Session: 2 (left lower lobe) for severe asthma
Patient: Sarah Mitchell, 42-year-old female with severe persistent asthma uncontrolled on biologic therapy.
Sedation: Deep sedation with propofol infusion, native airway with bite block.
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscope advanced to segmental and subsegmental bronchi in left lower lobe. Bronchial thermoplasty catheter deployed and RF energy delivered per protocol. Total activations delivered: 50.
Complications: Mild transient bronchospasm treated with nebulized albuterol; no intubation required.
Disposition: Observed in bronchoscopy recovery for 6 hours and discharged home on prednisone taper.

note_text:
Bronchial Thermoplasty Procedure Note (Aborted)
Session: 1 (right lower lobe)
Patient: David Nguyen, 50-year-old male with severe steroid-dependent asthma.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl.
Course: After initial BT activations in RLL basal segments (12 activations delivered), patient developed severe bronchospasm and hypoxia despite bronchodilator therapy. Procedure aborted and no further activations performed.
Complications: Acute asthma exacerbation requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation in ICU.
Disposition: Intubated, transferred to ICU for management.

note_text:
Medical Thoracoscopy Procedure Note
Procedure: Diagnostic medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies (no pleurodesis)
Patient: Patricia Foster, 62-year-old female with unilateral right exudative pleural effusion, concern for tuberculous pleuritis vs malignancy.
Sedation: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl plus local anesthesia.
Technique: Under ultrasound guidance, right 7th intercostal space selected. Approximately 1200 mL of straw-colored fluid drained. Semi-rigid thoracoscope introduced, revealing diffuse fibrinous exudate and scattered small nodules.
Multiple parietal pleural biopsies obtained; no talc instilled.
Complications: None.
Disposition: Chest tube left to water seal; admitted to ward.

registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs and tube management; outpatient follow-up after pathology

note_text:
Therapeutic Thoracentesis Note
Procedure: Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis complicated by small pneumothorax
Patient: William Carter, 79-year-old male with recurrent left pleural effusion and heart failure.
Sedation: Local anesthesia only.
Details: Using real-time ultrasound, left 8th intercostal space in posterior axillary line chosen. 1100 mL of clear straw-colored fluid removed via catheter. Patient developed mild pleuritic pain and cough at end of drainage; postprocedure ultrasound and CXR showed small apical pneumothorax.
No chest tube placed; patient observed with supplemental oxygen.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for monitoring.
